docs.lead_paragraph: For years, health insurers have occasionally demanded a look at psychotherapists' notes of their sessions with patients, to ensure that the care they were paying for was appropriate, or that it actually took place. But now one insurer, Oxford Health Plans, is saying that in many cases, the notes are not enough evidence that the patients received what Oxford paid for. Oxford has audited hundreds of psychiatrists, psychologists and social workers in the New York metropolitan area, deemed their notes inadequate documentation of the sessions, and demanded repayment of thousands of dollars from each provider -- in some cases, more than $100,000.

headline.main: Insurer Seeks Return of Fees For Therapy

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans has audited hundreds of mental health providers in New York metropolitan area and is demanding repayment of thousands of dollars, saying their notes are inadequate documentation to have paid claims; providers say Oxford has refused to say what standard of documentation they need to meet, although company rejects assertion; counselors fear patients might feel inhibited if they think written record of their revelations would be accessible; others predict exodus from Oxford by therapists (M)
docs.snippet: For years, health insurers have occasionally demanded a look at psychotherapists' notes of their sessions with patients, to ensure that the care they were paying for was appropriate, or that it actually took place.    But now one insurer, Oxford...

docs.lead_paragraph: The 19-day faculty members' strike at C. W. Post College in Brookville, N.Y., ended yesterday as union members unanimously ratified a three-year contract and prepared to return to their classrooms on Monday. The college has a history of bitter labor relations with faculty members, including repeated strikes over the years. The college is a branch of Long Island University. A separate faculty members' union at its Brooklyn campus also went on strike this month and settled on a new contract two weeks ago.

headline.main: 3-Year Deal Ends a Strike By the Faculty At C.W. Post

docs.abstract: Union members ratify three-year contract ending 19-day faculty strike at C W Post College, part of Long Island University; settlement provides wage increases over three years, plus bonuses to address salary inequities; college has history of bitter relations with faculty members (M)
docs.snippet: The 19-day faculty members' strike at C. W. Post College in Brookville, N.Y., ended yesterday as union members unanimously ratified a three-year contract and prepared to return to their classrooms on Monday.    The college has a history of bitter...

docs.lead_paragraph: The lower house of Parliament, the Bundestag, overwhelmingly passed the government's proposal for changes in the health care system. The vote was 517 to 54 for the package, the first in a series of tough reforms designed to revive the country's economy. Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's center-left government intends to cut health spending by more than $23 billion in the next four years, making the health system more efficient and shifting more costs to patients. Victor Homola (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany Health Package Approved

docs.abstract: Bundestag, lower house of German Parliament, overwhelmingly approves health reforms that Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's government hopes will make health system more efficient and shift more costs to patients (S)
docs.snippet: The lower house of Parliament, the Bundestag, overwhelmingly passed the government's proposal for changes in the health care system. The vote was 517 to 54 for the package, the first in a series of tough reforms designed to revive the country's...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Farmers Insurance Group said yesterday that it would stop selling medical malpractice insurance, narrowing an already tight market for physicians in some of the 18 states that it served. Farmers Insurance lost more than $100 million last year on malpractice policies, said Michelle Levy, a spokeswoman. She said the company, owned by the Swiss insurance giant Zurich Financial Services, planned to refocus on its core lines of home, business, auto and life insurance. Farmers Insurance stopped writing new medical malpractice policies last Friday and plans to halt renewals on Jan. 1, subject to the approval of insurance regulators. It has active malpractice policies valued at $94.5 million, and held more than 10 percent of the medical malpractice market in Oregon, Idaho and Missouri last year, Ms. Levy said.

headline.main: FARMERS TO STOP SELLING MALPRACTICE POLICIES

docs.abstract: Farmers Insurance Group will stop selling medical malpractice insurance, narrowing already tight market for physicians in some of 18 states that it served; company lost more than $100 million last year on malpractice policies (S)
docs.snippet: The Farmers Insurance Group said yesterday that it would stop selling medical malpractice insurance, narrowing an already tight market for physicians in some of the 18 states that it served. Farmers Insurance lost more than $100 million last year on...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential candidates squabbled intensely over tax cuts, health care and trade policy yesterday afternoon at a debate in Manhattan, trading often personal attacks. But the newest entrant to the race, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, stood on the sidelines and was largely ignored for much of the first debate of his political career. The third official debate of the Democratic presidential contest, held at the downtown campus of Pace University, drew more attention because of the general. The reporter contingent alone filled a basement gymnasium, and the candidates -- including General Clark -- arrived with large numbers of aides and advisers.

headline.main: Some Sharp Exchanges in Democrats' Debate

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential candidates, in their third official debate, squabble intensely over tax cuts, health care and trade policy, but largely ignore newest entrant Gen Wesley K Clark; debate is held at downtown Manhattan campus of Pace Univ; Clark's debut is overshadowed by detailed and often sharp disagreements about defining issues like tax cuts among nine other Democrats; Howard Dean--not Clark--draws most fire; in sharpest exchange, Rep Dick Gephardt accuses Dean of 'winging it' in matter of health care and Dean responds by saying he has done more for health insurance than Gephardt ever has; Clark, recently registered Democrat whose views on several issues are not yet known, even to supporters, seeks to reassure Democrats that he is in line with some of party's basic positions; decision by some of better-known candidates to attack one another and ignore Clark has effect of allowing him to appear way his aides have sought: fresh face above the fray; photo of candidates: Clark, Gephardt, Dean, Sens John Kerry, Joseph I Lieberman, Bob Graham and John Edwards, Rep Dennis J Kucinich, Al Sharpton and Carol Moseley Braun (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey and St. Barnabas Health Care System, a group of nine hospitals, reached agreement yesterday on a new contract, resolving a disagreement that threatened to disrupt coverage for thousands of customers. St. Barnabas had threatened last week to stop accepting Horizon members after seven months of negotiations in which Horizon had refused to pay higher rates. Details of the agreement were not disclosed. Approximately 70,000 Horizon subscribers used the Barnabas system last year, with an estimated 200,000 members in the area of the hospitals likely to use them if necessary. Alicia Zubikowski (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Blue Cross And Hospital Reach Agreement

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush intervened in talks on a Medicare drug bill today, trying to galvanize negotiations that have been slowed by deep disagreements between Republicans from the House and those from the Senate. After a meeting with lawmakers working on the legislation, Mr. Bush said, ''The sentiment was optimistic.'' He said he believed that they could reach agreement on a comprehensive Medicare bill before Congress adjourns this year.

headline.main: Bush Prods Lawmakers to Step Up Pace of Medicare Talks

docs.abstract: Pres Bush intervenes in talks on Medicare drug bill, trying to galvanize negotiations that have been slowed by deep disagreements between Republicans from House and those from Senate; conservative Republican senators on conference committe, like Jon Kyl and Don Nickles, contend that House bill does not do enough to bring private plans into Medicare market; Bush administration officials are said to be privately encouraging Kyl; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Massachusetts sued 13 generic drug makers yesterday, accusing them of inflating the prices of medicines purchased by the state's Medicaid program by more than $50 million over several years. The suit against the 13 companies, including Barr Laboratories Inc., Mylan Laboratories Inc. and Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc., was filed in Federal District Court in Boston by the Massachusetts attorney general, Thomas F. Reilly. It does not involve any other states.

headline.main: Massachusetts Sues 13 Drug Makers Over Prices

docs.abstract: Massachusetts sues 13 generic drug makers, accusing them of inflating prices of medicines purchased by state's Medicaid program by more than $50 million over several years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the Democratic debate yesterday, Representative Richard A. Gephardt declared that Howard Dean had sided with Newt Gingrich, the former Republican speaker of the House, on the question of cutting spending for Medicare. It is a charge Mr. Gephardt has made several times on the campaign trail in the past two weeks. Dr. Dean responded yesterday, as he has before, that it was false and insulting to compare him to Mr. Gingrich and that, as a doctor, he was much more qualified to deal with Medicare than Mr. Gephardt was. ''Nobody up here deserves to be compared to Newt Gingrich,'' Dr. Dean declared.

headline.main: Dean on Medicare: Looking at Record

docs.abstract: Rep Richard A Gephardt says in Democratic presidential debate that Howard Dean sided with Newt Gingrich, former Republican Speaker of House, on question of cutting spending for Medicare; Dean angrily responds that while he does think Medicare is 'administered dreadfully' he would never act to get rid of Medicare, and that to compare him to Gingrich is insulting (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The five major candidates vying to replace Gov. Gray Davis met tonight for the first and probably last time, engaging in a spirited, substantive -- and sometimes sarcastic and personal -- debate over topics including the state's dismal budget mess and the wisdom of the Oct. 7 recall itself. The debate, which featured Lt. Gov. Cruz Bustamante, the only big-name Democrat in the race; the actor Arnold Schwarzenegger; State Senator Tom McClintock; Peter Camejo of the Green Party; and the television commentator Arianna Huffington, had been eagerly anticipated by California voters, who quickly put behind them a week of legal uncertainty that had threatened to delay the election.

headline.main: Rivals Mix Issues and Attacks In Free-for-All Recall Debate

docs.abstract: Five major candidates vying to replace Gov Gray Davis of California meet for first and probably last time, engaging in spirited, substantive--sometimes sarcastic and personal--debate over topics including state's dismal budget mess and wisdom of Oct 7 recall itself; debate may well prove pivotal over final 12 days of race; latest poll finds more than 90 percent of voters are following election closely and two-thirds say candidates' performances at debate would be significant factor in their vote; those in debate are Lt Gov Cruz Bustamante, Democrat, Arnold Schwarzenegger and State Sen Tom McClintock, Republicans, Green Party's Peter Camejo, and Arianna Huffington, independent; candidates spar over variety of issues, but relatively little time is devoted to target of recall itself, Gov Davis; much of debate is dominated by feisty exchanges, with repeated moments of candidates talking over one another and moderator Stan Statham expressing frustration with free-for-all; photo (M)
